author: wired blogs
text: date: fri, 10 dec 1999 14:48:57 +0100 from: hrafnkell eirikssonto: newsfeedback@wired.comsubject: iceland's genetic jackpoti disagree with some of the points raised in your article, "iceland's genetic jackpot," 10.dec.1999.let me start by saying that i'm icelandic and i have followed thedebate on the database very closely.first, you write: "if the project is approved, roche and decode genetics could effectively own the genes of the entireisland nation."this is [not true]. the database will not contain any genes or dnarecords. it will only contain health records. decode will notown the health records but they will have the right to do certain(not all) queries about relation between diseases and family relations.you also say: "the genealogy information would be encrypted by the data protection commission of iceland to insure that the identities are concealed."it has been pointed out that this encryption is of no use.decode can theoretically still find out what records belong to whom. this is because although names and social security numbers (the primary key in our national register) will be put through a one way hash function, family relation between individuals will be kept.by using the family relation decode can build a family relationtree. decode has the largest genealogy database in iceland and inthat database they have names and social security numbers. by matching the two trees they can find out who is who in the health record database. maximum likelihood search is the way todo it.decode and the icelandic government have tried to convince the nation that there is no problem with the security of the data because strong encryption is used. this is obviously not true. the security of the database relies on trust. that is, of course, not any worse than what we have today. i go to my doctor because i trust him, not because he uses rsa to encrypt my [records].then you write: "the psychiatric group said in a document that decode genetics could target insurance companies as possible clients."such use of the data is forbidden by the law. if they do that they will lose the licence and go to jail.
